results.title: Bush mechanics (A)
results.creator_credit: Francis Kelly, David Batty, Tom Kantor and Waripiri Media
results.brief_description: A documentary that takes a light-hearted look at the ingenious methods that Aboriginal men living in remote communities employ to keep their automobiles running. Without a trade certificate between them, these men have developed the unique craft of ‘bush mechanics’, adapting available resources for use as spare parts. The stories they relate provide a unique insight into this practical and philosophical approach to car maintenance and highlight many of the adaptive techniques desert people have developed through necessity over the last seventy years.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Francis Kelly, David Batty, Tom Kantor and Waripiri Media

results.title: Bush Mechanics
results.brief_description: David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience.

constellations_primary.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_primary.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

results.description:
David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) only ran for one season, but it became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience, where nyurulypa (good tricks) are used to keep wrecked cars on the red—sand roads of outback Australia. The cast use mulga wood, spinifex and clever hacks to showcase their ingenious approach to mechanics.

Demonstrating this winning combination of Warlpiri and car culture, Ngapa Jukuurpa (Water Dreaming) is painted on an old Ford ZF Fairlane in the series’ final episode. The Bush Mechanics drive the ‘Ngapa car’ to Broome to trade for pearl shells to use in a ceremony to break the drought.

“The core of Bush Mechanics was basically a road trip, where you had the crappest car in the world, and things would inevitably go wrong… so you have to innovate… things like stuffing a flat tyre with spinifex… or getting a tree and carving it to make a crankshaft. It became like a cult classic. It took the country, in a very quiet way, by storm.” – Rachel Perkins
description_for_label:

results.title: Bush Mechanics
results.brief_description:
This off-beat series follows the exploits of the Bush Mechanics, a group of engaging Aboriginal characters, as they travel through central Australia.

Combining adventure, magic, realism and a distinctive brand of humour, Bush Mechanics provides an insight into both contemporary and traditional Aboriginal culture.

results.title: Bush Mechanics
results.creator_credit: Francis Jupurrula Kelly, David Batty, Jennifer McMahon, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Warlpiri Media and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The “Bush Mechanics” comprise of a group of five young Warlpiri Aboriginal men from Yuendumu in the Northern Territory who can face any challenge when it comes to fixing cars, no matter what condition the car may be in! They will use the bush as a resource for spare parts and do whatever it takes to keep a car on the road. Their clever inventiveness, wonderfully offbeat humour and crazy antics, provide an insight into both contemporary and traditional Aboriginal culture. In the style of a road movie, this series follows the “Bush Mechanics” across the central desert, through their many mechanical mishaps, challenges and exploits, including the race to Willowra to play their first paying gig as a rock band, the travel to Alice Springs to collect Simeon’s nephew from jail, the chase for their stolen car and finally covering thousands of kilometers across the west to Broome to search for pearl shells for the rainmaker. The Bush Mechanics are: Simeon Jupurrula Ross, Steven Jupurrula Morton, Errol Jupurrula Nelson, Junior Jupurrula Wilson and Randall Jupurrula Wilson. Also features Jack Jakamurra Ross, and Francis Jupurrula Kelly. In English and Warlpiri with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Francis Jupurrula Kelly, David Batty, Jennifer McMahon, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Warlpiri Media and Film Australia

results.title: Bush mechanics
results.creator_credit: CAAMA, Indigenous Unit, AFC, Warlpiri Media, Tom Kantor, Francis Kelly and David Batty
results.brief_description:
A documentary that takes a light-hearted look at the ingenious methods that Aboriginal men living in remote communities employ to keep their automobiles running. Without a trade certificate between them, these men have developed the unique craft of ‘bush mechanics’ adapting
available resources for use as spare parts. The stories they relate provide an unique insight into this practical and philosophical approach to car maintenance and highlight many of the adaptive techniques desert people have developed through necessity over the last seventy years. This documentary spawned a television series produced by
the Australian Broadcasting Commission in association with Warlpiri Media. For more information go to: http://www.warlpiri.com.au/bushmechanics/bushmech.htm

results.title: Bush harvest
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Eucalyptus oil is distilled from the leaves of certain types of Australian eucalyptus trees. The film shows this being done by men who live and work in the bush and also some of the scientific research being carried out in order to determine the uses to which the different types of oil may be put. Photography: Frank Bagnall.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian National Film Board
results.description: Eucalyptus oil is distilled from the leaves of certain types of Australian eucalyptus trees. results.title: Bush doctor
results.creator_credit: Jean Palardy, Roger Blais and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Flying physician, Dr Paul-Leon Rivard, paper company doctor at Clova, Quebec, has a practice overing 6000 patients scattered over 50,000 square km of the Abitibi region. He manages to cover the wilderness by plane, dog team and snowshoe, to help wherever needed.

results.title: Bush corridors
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Justin Milne, South Australian Film Corporation and Newfilms
results.brief_description: This film will be of interest to the general public but it is designed primarily for farmers to convince them of the necessity of leaving areas of scrub uncleared. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Bush Christmas
results.creator_credit: Ralph Smart and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: Bush Christmas is a superb film which won critical acclaim around the world upon its release in 1947 and is today regarded as an Australian classic. In this 1971 re-edited version, a family of Australian children, realising their father’s horses have been stolen, set out to track the horse thieves and return the horses to their father as a Christmas present. A storm destroys their tracks and the children become lost, while search parties, and the horse thieves, desperately hunt for them. Starring Chips Rafferty.

results.title: Bush Christmas
results.creator_credit: Ralph Smart, Children's Entertainment Films and ABFD
results.brief_description: This brilliant Australian film depicts Yuletide life in country Australia in the 1940s. A family of children, whose father owns a horse farm, realise the horses have been stolen, so they set out to track the horse thieves in an effort to return the horses to their father as a Christmas present. A storm destroys their tracks and the children become lost, while search parties, and the horse thieves, one of which is played by Chips Rafferty, desperately hunt for them. This is a superb film which won critical acclaim around the world upon its release, and is regarded as an Australian classic. Narrated by John McCallum and filmed on location in the Blue Mountains and Burragorang Valley. Cast includes: John Fernside, Stan Tolhurst, Helen Grieve, Nicky Yardly, Edmund Allison.
